awd_titl_txt: IUSE/PFE:RED: Revolutionizing Engineering Education through Industry Immersion and a Focus on Identity
awd_abstract_narration:
The culture of a program or department plays a significant role in effective, inclusive, and innovative STEM education.  Despite immense efforts to diversify the student body in engineering programs, research suggests that department culture continues to challenge engineering education and the educators who are preparing the next generation of engineers. For example, too often engineering departments reflect a narrow, stereotypical view of what it means to be an engineer. Women and other underrepresented minorities who do not fit this view do not identify with engineering and this can lead to dissatisfaction and disengagement. This project implements a unique educational experience where students and faculty are immersed in a culture of doing engineering with industry engineers that in turn fosters an identity of being an engineer. This new culture will be created through a shared department vision and a deep immersion in industry and engineering practice. Some of the changes include faculty participation in industry, makeathons that connect industry professionals with students, and changes in how the department prioritizes teaching, student research, industry connections, and faculty mentoring.  Along with these activities, this project serves to investigate the effects of this new culture on the identity of students and faculty, and how these identity changes affect students' engagement, performance, and commitment to engineering. Identity describes who people think they are, what they think they can do and be, and where and with whom they think they belong. It is a pivotal factor in one's commitment and persistence in engineering, notably for women and minorities. Identity development is a social process realized through culture. Understanding how identities affect students, particularly females, could transform how we teach STEM K-16. Such knowledge will allow educators to target activities that produce the strongest effect on identity and be mindful of those that negatively impact identity. The result is better retention for a more diverse student body.

More specifically, during the project, changes to the engineering program and to student and faculty identities will be monitored through interviews, surveys, and many other tools. Results of the study will lead to a clearer understanding of the changes that promote engineering identities, particularly in women, and how such identities affect students' sense of belonging in a program and their persistence in the major. The study will also lead to a better understanding of the factors that influence faculty identity, and how these richer identities affect how they view their roles and their students. Key activities of this project include: (1) the creation of opportunities for students to do realistic engineering, (2) an industry immersion experience for faculty and teacher training, (3) revising the curriculum to include connections to practice, (4) and implementing reflection and portfolios for assessment of professional engineering identity development.  In the curriculum, this immersion will be achieved by integrating experiential learning throughout as the connecting thread. Housed in a mechanical engineering department, this project has the potential to impact engineering education by offering a model and best practices in which the engineering identities of students and faculty can be transformed by the immersion in real-world engineering. This project is jointly funded by the Division of Undergraduate Education; the Division of Engineering Education and Centers; the Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation; the Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems; and the Division of Industrial Innovation and Partnerships; reflecting the alignment of this project with the respective goals of the divisions and their programs.

por.por_cntn:
From 2017 to 2023, the Mechanical Engineering Department at Seattle University developed a culture of “Engineering with Engineers,” to foster engineering identity. When students identify as engineers, they no longer see themselves as college students who graduate and then become engineers. They see themselves as engineers in the process of developing skills, knowledge, and experience. This sense of engineering identity and belonging leads to students who are more committed and will persist longer in the field and has been shown to be important in retaining women and underrepresented minorities in engineering.

This culture was created through changes in four areas that research indicates are essential: a shared department vision, reflective faculty, relevant curriculum, and supportive policies. Overall, the department undertook 54 distinct endeavors to develop this culture; ten of those were both especially critical (impactful) to the culture change and relatively transferrable to other programs. In alphabetical order, these ten endeavors are summarized below. 

  1. Annual Performance Review (APR): The APR was used as a tool for recognizing and rewarding faculty for their efforts in contributing to the department’s culture and for motivating faculty to continue. The Department’s new approach is consistent with the University’s new tenure and promotion guidelines.
  2. Curriculum: The curriculum was revised through a collaboration of faculty, staff, and students with the goals of developing student's engineering identity and preparing students for engineering practice. The curriculum incorporated three new vertical design experience courses (Integrated Design Projects - IDP) and a new integrated Electrical Engineering and Data Acquisition course sequence. Data from these courses indicate that they are successful in terms of meeting learning outcomes, connecting to real-world engineering, and increasing belonging and inclusion. 
  3. Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI): The curriculum undertook several DEI-related changes including standardizing and implementing a department-wide DEI statement in courses, regular DEI training for faculty, and changing how some courses and labs were taught.  The goal was to help women and underrepresented minorities feel a sense of belonging to and identification with the department. Data from our external evaluator indicate the development of a more inclusive environment.
  4. Engineers in Training (EIT): The senior capstone sequence pivoted away from academic language and schedules to those used in engineering practice. Results from the Senior Growth Survey indicate significant development in seniors’ growth as professionals.
  5. Industry Connection: The program strengthened its connections with industry by hiring a resident industry advisor, implementing a summer immersion experience that allowed faculty to work in industry, and infusing industry practices in such courses as IDP and senior design.
  6. Innovative Teaching: The department promoted and encouraged innovative teaching. Teaching innovations included the adoption of flipped classrooms, industry projects in classes, recognition of the importance of DEI in an engineering curriculum, and lessons learned from remote teaching during the pandemic.    
  7. Mission Statement: The department established a shared understanding by reviewing and updating its mission statement using a co-design process. The process resulted in an experience of working together, trust that the group can succeed when it works together, and a commitment to the collaboratively created revised mission statement. Co-designing the mission statement early in the RED project set the stage for other successful endeavors. 
  8. Retreats: The department prioritized the importance of meaningful retreats. A team spent time establishing retreat goals and activities that involved all faculty and staff. These retreats moved the department’s culture change forward and brought faculty and staff together.
  9. Staff: The department emphasized the importance staff play in the student experience. The department assigned new expectations for new hires and emphasized the lab manager and senior administrative assistant staff positions during conversations regarding curriculum change, retention of students, and other matters.
  10. Teaming: The department began holding dedicated meetings (Teaming) designed to build trust and collaboration among faculty and staff members. Teaming is a form of group discussion that requires no preparation for the participants, starts with a simple prompt that can be answered by everyone present, and helps the group build trust through dialogues.

As a result of the endeavors taken during the grant, the program is enjoying a newfound professional culture of collaboration, supported by stronger industry connections, improvements to the curriculum and courses, a growing commitment to gender equity and inclusiveness, and increasing belonging and identity. These cultural changes are evident through interviews and observations conducted by an external evaluator and are further supported by faculty and student feedback and our own data collection.

In addition to program changes, the project produced more than thirty-five products, including eighteen journal and juried conference papers, invited plenary sessions, numerous nationwide workshops, three online co-design workshops attended by around forty educators in each session, a program to conduct an Implicit Association Test on mobile devices, and a web site sured.org titled Inspiration Kit that highlights the useful results of the project.  


Last Modified: 01/29/2024
Modified by: Teodora R Shuman
